title: CryptSafe
author: CryptSafe
created_time: November 19, 2022, 10:49:07 PMLast edit: November 20, 2022, 03:32:30 PM by CryptSafe
content: In line with the global adoption and promotion of bitcoin for which  I am a member of this community, fulfilling one of the course for which this community have long being on the move. I decided to take the bitcoin adoption and promotion movement to my locality. My major targets are vendors, traders, skilled and unskilled labors in my locality and my neighborhood. To start with, I met this barber in my locality, he is good at his work and gives nice haircut. I took my time to talk with him about bitcoin and how it works.  At the first stance, he was reluctant and said he does not really have digital knowledge and it would be a kind of difficult for him to go through it but I assured him he would like it when I start putting him through the whole process and he gave in. I started by giving him hint on technological innovation towards digital currency with Bitcoin as topic and subject of discussion. He picked interest in the discussion and started asking me questions about bitcoin and how it works for which I responded to him accurately. It was an interesting and interactive session as I made him understand the whole system and how it works.In other for the communication, learning and teaching process to scale through, I had to come up with a learning scheme for an easier understanding and they are as follows;1. What is Bitcoin?2. When and why Bitcoin was founded.3. Founder of Bitcoin.4. Importance and benefits of holding bitcoin.5. How to trade bitcoin. ( listed some  notable exchange where he can trade bitcoin)6. What is blockchain and how it works.As a first timer, I explained and showed him what a public and private key looks like, showing him a transaction harsh too was another thing I did for him to get a clearer picture of how it works.Never the less, I taught him how to set up a bitcoin wallet, the easiest to be precise so he could easily understand and do it himself, copy and send his wallet address to his customers for payment. As earlier mentioned above, I also told and showed him the difference between private keys, public keys  and transaction harsh so he could get acquainted to them all. For accepting bitcoin as a means of payment, I promised to patronizing him and also introduce him to more customers ready and willing to pay with bitcoin for services rendered  within my locality. He was very happy for my kind gesture of me introducing him to new customers ready and willing to pay in bitcoin which means a plus to his business. It was nice and also fun on-boarding him into the bitcoin movement. I believe he too can reach out to his fellows as I told him to do so because it would aid in the faster and rapid adoption and promotion of bitcoin in other locality where they belong. This course we must achieve until bitcoin adoption gets to the various locality as this is the grassroots goal on target.Edit.....I will keep updating this tread as I continue to carry on with the Bitcoin Promotion and Adoption  campaign in various locality.

comments.author: Kakmakr
comments.body: The thing is... You can introduce someone to Bitcoin and you can even inspire them to accept it as a payment option in their shop or business, but if there are not people using it as a currency.... those businesses will stop accepting it as a payment option. Bitcoin's volatility encourage people to rather use Bitcoin as a Commodity or an investment ...so people are hesitant to use it as a "Currency" ...because they anticipate huge profits on the horizon.

comments.author: The Cryptovator
comments.body: Incredible, mate! To be honest, you're doing an admirable job. It is not an easy task to reach out to people and explain Bitcoin to them. Because it's difficult to explain Bitcoin or cryptocurrency to someone who is completely unfamiliar with them. However, I assume cryptocurrency is legal in your country and that helping to promote Bitcoin will not cause you any problems. If there is an opportunity, that is how we can all adapt Bitcoin. Unfortunately, Bitcoin is not legal in my country, so I cannot do the same. I just tried to explain Bitcoin to my very close friend.

comments.author: buwaytress
comments.body: Nice one, OP! As hugeblack wrote, though, motivation is what really ensures that the people you're targeting (in this case, his potential or existing customers) are converted to try using BTC at least once.How do you convince them? When they understand why you do it -- some reasons or motivations given (opportunity to send money to places inaccessible by traditional payments, inflation hedge etc.).But even more powerful for me is to demonstrate the positive change (before and after).Example (from perspective of the shop owner): before, I couldn't accept Mister A as customer because he could not leave his farm. Now, I send him a payment request for BTC and I now have a new customer.
